Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Deciphering the Beat of a Timeless Rhythm- The Future of Astrochronology
Award.AbstractNarration:
CAREER: Deciphering the Beat of a Timeless Rhythm - The Future of Astrochronology

Stephen Meyers
University of Wisconsin
EAR-1151438


The geologic record provides the only available documentation of long-term environmental change, but in order to accurately interpret this record and evaluate rates of change we require a means to tell time. The dating of sedimentary deposits via astrochronology has become one of the most important tools for construction of the state-of-the-art geologic time scale. This method utilizes the geologic record of climate oscillations - those ascribed to quasi-periodic changes in the Earth's orbit and rotation - to measure the passage of time directly from repetitive sedimentary layers. The impact of astrochronology on the quantification of 'deep-time' has been truly revolutionary, and the approach is now even employed to fine-tune (e.g., calibrate) radioisotopic data and to test their veracity. However, although the method has resulted in the development of extraordinary high-resolution time scales, the uncertainties in deep-time astrochronologies are almost uniformly poorly constrained. This CAREER project will address the three fundamental challenges to the field of deep-time astrochronology using a new computational approach, with the goal of enhancing the accuracy and precision of an astronomically tuned geologic time scale.

The first of the challenges to deep-time astrochronology arises from the near ubiquitous lack of adequate independent time control (e.g., radioisotopic data with sufficiently small errors) to unambiguously calibrate observed spatial rhythms to temporal periods, which prohibits direct confirmation of the proposed astronomical tempo. This shortcoming has resulted in much confusion, including multiple incompatible interpretations for a given stratigraphic record, and has also roused suspicion about the veracity of astrochronology. The second major challenge is the corruption of the orbital insolation signal as it propagates through the climate system and into various depositional systems (including sedimentation rate changes and hiatus), which may ultimately render the preserved astronomical signature unidentifiable, or worse yet, result in erroneous inferences about the preserved tempo. The third major challenge to deep-time astrochronology is the lack of accurate orbital insolation solutions beyond ~50 Ma, which necessitates the distinction between 'floating' and 'anchored' astrochronologies. These three challenges will be addressed by uniting and building upon important scientific advances within the fields of Quaternary paleoclimate, cyclostratigraphy, geochronology and geophysics. The new computational approach will provide fundamental methodological advances towards the achievement of an astronomically tuned Phanerozoic time scale, and will yield a more complete understanding of how orbital insolation changes influenced the surficial Earth System during both icehouse and greenhouse intervals of Earth history. As a test case for the new methodology, this project will evaluate the Eocene Green River Formation, a stratigraphic unit of great historical significance to the field of cyclostratigraphy.

A central feature of this CAREER project is the integration of research and education. Involvement in the UW-Madison PEOPLE program engages youth in scientific discovery, and increases underrepresented minority participation in Geoscience. Partnership with colleagues at the UW-Madison Geology Museum will culminate in the development of a new geologic time display that will be seen by ~45,000 visitors per year, and participation in their science outreach program will result in a new model railroad exhibit (the 'Deep-Time Express') to be deployed at large public events. Establishment of a national research hub for the intercalibration of astrochronologic and radioisotopic time scales will build community within the field of geochronology, and will facilitate the distribution of software and tutorials generated for the project. Finally, the development of courses in chronostratigraphy and cyclostratigraphy, coupled with student participation in research, will provide a unique interdisciplinary training for the integration of astrochronologic and radioisotopic time scales, thus cultivating future leaders in the field of geochronology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Intellectual Merit

The long history of our planet provides a rich tapestry of boundary conditions and past climate 'experiments', which can be used to understand how the Earth System works, and can thus inform decisions about our future.  The geological record is, in fact, the only available documentation of long-term environmental change and the factors that influence it.  But how do we decode that history from a complex and noisy rock record?  

This NSF CAREER project has focused on one approach to decode the geological record, using regular cyclic variations in Earth's orbit and rotational axis (Milankovitch cycles) as a central framework to reconstruct the behavior of the ancient Earth System, and the Solar System, over the past several billion years.  A primary achievement of the project is the development of a new statistical framework - and accompanying open source software - that addresses the major challenges in the field of 'astrochronology', including a comprehensive treatment of uncertainty.  This now allows extension of the field of astrochronology into the deepest stretches of Earth history (billions of years ago), and facilitates improvement in the calibration of the geologic time scale.

Application of the new statistical framework has resulted in several major advances in knowledge, spanning such topic as the history of the Moon, characterization of ancient Solar System behavior and chaos, the geological history of biological diversity, and the future of the Antarctic ice sheet.  Several of these major advances in knowledge are highlighted below. In total, 18 peer-reviewed scientific articles have been published to date.

Confirmation of Solar System Chaos

Ma et al. (Nature, 2017) provide the first definitive confirmation of Solar System chaos, an idea that was originally proposed by astronomer Jacques Laskar in 1989.  The implications of this new finding are far reaching, as outlined in this news release about the paper:

https://news.wisc.edu/from-rocks-in-colorado-evidence-of-a-chaotic-solar-system

Reconstruction of Ancient Milankovitch Cycles, Solar System Behavior, and Earth-Moon History

Meyers & Malinverno (Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 2018) develop a new approach that maps out ancient Solar System behavior and Earth-Moon history using the geological archive. The method also provides robust quantitative uncertainties on ancient Milankovitch cycles, and derived astronomical time-scales. As a consequence, the temporal resolution of ancient Earth System processes is enhanced, and our knowledge of early Solar System dynamics is greatly improved. A news release can be found here:

https://news.wisc.edu/thank-the-moon-for-earths-lengthening-day

Biological Evolution Driven by Milankovitch Forcing

Crampton et al. (Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 2018) develop a new quantitative approach for cyclostratigraphy, which is applied to confirm the existence of Milankovitch cycles in the Early Paleozoic Era and shows that known processes related to the mechanics of the Solar System were shaping marine macroevolutionary rates comparatively early in the history of complex life.  A news release can be found here:

https://www.victoria.ac.nz/news/2018/05/fossil-record-reveals-changes-in-earths-movement-and-rotation

Decoding the History and Future of the Antarctic Ice Sheet

Levy et al. (Nature Geoscience, 2019) provide a new evaluation of the late Cenozoic history of the Antarctic Ice Sheet, revealing major phases of its growth and decay, with implications for the future of the ice sheet. A news release can be found here:

https://news.wisc.edu/antarctic-ice-sheet-could-suffer-a-one-two-climate-punch

2. Broader Impact

A central feature of this CAREER is the integration of research and education, to enhance scientific literacy among the general public, cultivate future leaders in geoscience, and foster a strong scientific community. These contributions include:

  • The development of Astrochron (https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/astrochron), a new 'open-source' computational platform for conducting, and learning about: (1) paleoclimate time series analysis, (2) astronomical time scale construction, and (3) the statistical integration of astrochronologies with other geochronologic/chronostratigraphic data. The project has facilitated efficient and transparent communication of analytical approaches used in astrochronology, enabling rapid verification of results, while fostering science and methodological innovation through community involvement.
  • Creation and implementation of the IsoAstro Geochronology Workshops (2014, 2016, 2019) built community within the discipline, provided advanced training to participants, and facilitated the distribution of programs and tutorials generated for the project. These objectives were also achieved through lecturing at the Urbino Summer School in Paleoclimatology (2014, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018), the ECORD Summer School: "Deep-Sea Sediments: From Stratigraphy to Age Models" (2013), the International Geoscience Programme Project 591 Closing Meeting (2016), and numerous other short courses (GNS Science 2015; Lamont-Doherty 2016).
  • Partnership with the UW-Madison Geology Museum culminated in the development of a new geologic time display that is seen by ~45,000 visitors per year.  Participation in their 'guerrilla science' outreach engaged the general public.
  • Involvement in the UW-Madison PEOPLE program (https://peopleprogram.wisc.edu), and a range of outreach activities at grade schools, engaged youth in scientific discovery.
  • Development of graduate courses at UW-Madison provided interdisciplinary training in astrochronology, paleoclimatology and geochronology. Coursework built on key innovations of this project (e.g., Astrochron).
  • The project trained and supported five UW-Madison Ph.D. students and two UW-Madison M.S. students.
